summary: This document contains administrative records from the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration, including suicide watch observation logs, internal emails about suicide risk assessments, media inquiries, and correspondence about legal visits. It reveals official concerns about Epstein's suicide risk prior to his death and internal communications following reports about guards skipping checks. This document outlines the detailed visiting procedures, attorney-client communication protocols, and mail handling regulations for the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It specifies rules for attorney visits, legal representatives, co-defendant meetings, telephone calls, and legal mail, emphasizing security protocols and attorney-client privilege protections. This document is a detailed procedures manual from the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, outlining policies for inmate legal access, mail, discovery, medical services, administrative remedies, and other institutional operations. It appears to be a standard guide for attorneys and inmates, with no specific references to the Epstein case or individuals involved in it. This document is a collection of internal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) emails and forms from July-August 2019 concerning Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and death. It includes a media statement about his location, internal discussions about his mental state, procedures for releasing his funds, and a standard BOP application form for legal representatives to visit inmates. This document contains internal Bureau of Prisons emails and administrative forms (SHU Review forms BP-A295 052) from August 2019 concerning the monitoring and review of Jeffrey Epstein's status in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York, in the days and weeks leading up to his death. It includes requests for data reconstruction after his death and logs showing he was moved in and out of SHU and placed under observation with an inmate companion.

keyFacts: Official suicide watch logs were maintained for Jeffrey Epstein at MCC New York in July 2019.

Bureau of Prisons psychology staff identified Epstein as having multiple risk factors for suicidality, including his high-profile case, sex offense charges, and pre-trial status, and proactively recommended a suicide risk assessment.
Internal emails from July 8, 2019, show prison officials were concerned Epstein would receive 'bad news' in court and needed close monitoring.
Following Epstein's death, internal emails from August 11, 2019, discuss a Reuters report alleging guards skipped mandatory checks, with an official expressing disbelief at the leak.
A paralegal for Epstein's legal team, Samanta Honigman, had to renew her application for visiting privileges in July 2019, indicating ongoing legal preparation.
The document details strict security protocols for attorney visits at MCC New York, including metal detector screening, contraband restrictions, and dress code requirements.
Attorneys can bring legal materials and use institutional equipment (computers, VCRs) to review discovery with clients, but electronic equipment is prohibited from being brought in.
Co-defendant meetings require 24-hour advance written request, proof of co-defendant status, and may be prohibited by separation orders unless approved by the Assistant U.S. Attorney.
Inmates can place unmonitored attorney calls only with Unit Team approval, demonstrating other communication methods are inadequate; regular inmate calls are monitored and recorded.

Legal mail must be clearly marked with attorney's name, status, and 'Special Mail - Open only in presence of inmate' to receive confidential handling; packages require additional 'Authorized by Bureau Policy' marking.
The document is a comprehensive institutional procedures manual for MCC New York, detailing legal mail, discovery access, medical services, and administrative grievance processes.
It specifies that inmates can access discovery materials on CD-ROM in the law library, with supported formats including PDF, AVI, MPG, MP3, and DOC files.
The manual outlines the multi-step Administrative Remedy Program (BP-9, BP-10, BP-11) for inmates to formally grieve conditions of confinement.
It notes that inmates are initially placed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) upon arrival for screening before being assigned to general population or remaining in SHU.
The document includes an attachment (Attachment A) which is a visitor/correspondent questionnaire requiring background checks for legal visits, with processing taking a minimum of 14 days.
On July 25, 2019, the BOP publicly confirmed Jeffrey Epstein was housed at MCC New York and not in a hospital, refusing to comment on his medical status.
Internal BOP emails from August 10, 2019, show staff reacting with disbelief to a news report that prison guards skipped mandatory checks before Epstein's death.
A mental health professional visited Epstein in the SHU on August 8, 2019, and reported he denied suicidal thoughts, was not distressed, and was focused on practical requests.
After Epstein's death, BOP staff held his inmate trust account funds ($566.27) instead of following the normal procedure to release them to next-of-kin, citing the unusual circumstances.

The document includes a standard BOP application form (Form B2-A0660.012) for paralegals, interpreters, and private investigators to gain access to federal prisoners as representatives of licensed attorneys.
Internal BOP emails from August 12, 2019, show a directive to urgently reconstruct Epstein's SHU record for the week prior to his death (August 5-9, 2019).
Epstein was moved in and out of the Special Housing Unit (SHU) three times between July 7, 2019, and August 10, 2019.
One SHU placement form lists the reason as 'PENDING DHO FOR CODE 228 SELF-MUTILATION', indicating a prior incident of self-harm.
A log shows Epstein was assigned an 'inmate companion' and was transferred to psychological observation in late July 2019.
The documents are part of the post-death administrative review and data collection ordered by BOP officials.
